awd_titl_txt: SCC-CIVIC-FA Track B: Hoomalu Halelea - Community-led Innovation for Integrated Flood Resilience
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project, a team of academic and community partners will combine diverse methods and sources of knowledge of watershed changes over time to enhance community resilience to increasing threats of extreme flooding in coastal communities. Like other locales around the world, the project's site of Halelea, a rural district on Island of Kauai, Hawaii, is on the cusp of the climate crisis. In April 2018, an extreme rain event in Halelea set a new US 24-hr rainfall record (49.7”) and caused $19.7M in losses due to flooding. Since then, flooding and landslides have reoccurred frequently. Traditional knowledge and oversight of water resources, built across generations, is no longer sufficient due to changes in rainfall, species invasion, and land use change. In collaboration with community members, nonprofits who have led flood and disaster response, and the Kauai Emergency Management Agency, this project will enhance resilience to increasing flood risk in coastal communities by strengthening connections of community members with one another and their environment, as well as with local government, tourists, and newer residents. Additionally, the team is distilling best practices in developing an inclusive, community-based environmental management approach for coastal areas and participating in on-going knowledge sharing with coastal communities including the Pacific Islands and the continental US.

The vision of this project is to enhance social and ecological community resilience to increasing flood risk by linking Indigenous knowledge, local observations of ecological change, and data from scientific instrumentation. This approach will improve capacity for mountain-to-sea watershed management, while connecting future generations to their responsibilities for reciprocal care. The work addresses the following specific project goals: (1) Collaborative Research: Work with community members to integrate diverse methods and sources of knowledge of watershed changes over time to enhance local level care and management of streams; (2) Restoration: Enhance effectiveness of stream clearing and restoration efforts; (3) Monitoring and Communication: Improve availability of historical and real-time hydrometeorological data to enhance understanding of flood hazards, and promote use of social media to improve community connectedness before, during, and after extreme events; and (4) Community Education and Training: Provide classes and educational material, in community-identified topics, to enhance holistic resilience to future climate-change induced disasters. This project is part of the Civic Innovation Challenge, a collaboration between NSF, the Department of Energy's Vehicle Technology Office, and the Department of Homeland Security's Science and Technology Directorate and Federal Emergency Management Agency.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Hoomalu Halelea focused on enhancing community-based flood resilience in Halelea, which is on the north shore of the Hawaiian island of Kauai and broke the U.S. 24-hour rainfall record during flooding in 2018. The project was a collaboration between The Hanalei Initiative, five other Halelea community nonprofits, the County of Kauai Emergency Management Agency, and the University of Hawaii at Manoa, Water Resources Research Center.

 

Intellectual Merit:

Through collaborative ecosystem-based research Hoʻomalu Haleleʻa advanced knowledge in four distinct academic fields including hydrology, atmospheric science, community-based natural resource management, and climate change resilience while yielding insights across disciplines. Our in-depth study of two watersheds enhances understanding of hydrological variability, across time, and within even small geographical areas, while amplifying the impacts of invasive species on flooding. This project piloted methods for enhancing climate and atmospheric science models, often based on remote sensed readings, with real time, place-based data and indigenous knowledge to provide more contextualized, nuanced and holistic information and predictions. Finally, Hoʻomalu Haleleʻa expanded frameworks of social-ecological resilience to include the concept of connectivity; of people to place, between individuals and organizations within communities, of historic and evolving knowledge across generations, and of waterways and resource management from mountain to sea. The project highlights less recognized threats to local level resilience to climate change, such as tourism in remote areas, while supporting factors that build community adaptation, such as cross-generational ties, availability of jobs caring for the environment, and cross-scale networks.

 

Hoʻomalu Haleleʻa also modeled approaches to, lessons for, and impacts of collaborative, community led, ecosystem-based research weaving indigenous and western science, and how this work requires flexibility and time. In another result bridging intellectual merit and broader outcomes, our team identified and mapped over twenty abandoned weather stations in the mountains of our project site left by past grant funded research teams. After we learned how past researchers eroded community trust and goodwill when equipment they installed was left to decay in sacred landscapes, we opted to spend helicopter funding hauling four loads of abandoned weather station refuse from sensitive sites, rather than erecting new ones.

Researchers everywhere should include plans for equipment disposal and removal as part of funded projects in order to respect community partners, the lands and waters where we work. 

 

Broader Impacts:

 Hoʻomalu Haleleʻa increased understanding of social and ecological factors contributing to and recommendations for reducing flood risk in Haleleʻa, potentially enhancing safety and adaptive response in this highly vulnerable and visited community, along with others across the U.S. and Pacific facing similar conditions. Two teaching exchanges with Hana, Maui, a partner community within Hawaiʻi experiencing similar flooding and road closure challenges, were especially valued by participants. In addition to face-to-face sharing, our project created multiple interactive information platforms including a website with story maps and historic genealogies of watersheds, linked to real time camera, road conditions, and weather station data for community members, government officials, businesses, and tourists. These products offer creative approaches for monitoring and communication to enhance safety and resilience in other flood prone communities. 

https://storymaps.arcgis.com/stories/bb17de35b7ea449fa89954ca444c2715 

The project also provides a model for stream risk assessment and watershed management in flood prone areas, with cost effective methods community members of all ages, even children, can employ, such as bark stripping. We removed over 300 hazardous invasive albizia trees and trained over 50 community members, 15 teachers, 200 elementary, and 15 college-age students in monitoring of water quality and native biota, hazard identification, and invasive species management through workshops, field trips, summer programs, and integrated watershed curricula. The project enhanced diversity, through increasing training and employability for all project personnel, over 75% women, and over 60% from minority and underrepresented groups, including four female PIs, three Asian and Pacific Islanders. Five masters’ students earned degrees in political and atmospheric sciences, hydrology, indigenous and environmental science, all obtaining employment upon graduation, while one post-doc, five PIs, two community leads, five community staff members, and five area nonprofits enhanced their skills in in collaborative, applied ecosystem research and climate adaptation. The project reached over 400 additional academics and practitioners across the Hawaiʻi, the U.S. and abroad through presentations and exchange. Hoomalu Halelea also strengthened partnerships among Halelea area nonprofits resulting in a successful collaborative 5 million dollar grant award to continue stream restoration and management approaches piloted in this grant, as well as sharing learning from these efforts. Finally, the project enhanced community-led resilience to future climate-induced disasters in the project site and beyond, by training future generations to care for dynamic watersheds mountain to sea, guided by indigenous science and connection to place, while adapting to ecological change.
